ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Radixin N-ERMAD interacts with the integrin β cytoplasmic tail. (A) Radixin N-ERMAD recognizes the β2 cytoplasmic domain. A 96-well plate was coated with either the αM (∘, ▵) or β2 cytoplasmic peptides (•, ▴), blocked, and then incubated with GST-radixin N-ERMAD (∘, •) or GST-C-ERMAD (▵, ▴). After washing, bound proteins were determined. (B) Radixin C-ERMAD blocks N-ERMAD binding to the β2 cytoplasmic tail. Binding of radixin N-ERMAD to the αM (filled bar) or β2 (open bar) peptides were conducted as described above, except that different concentrations of His-tagged radixin C-ERMAD were added. Data are means±S.D. of duplicate samples and are representative of three independent experiments.

Radixin recognizes the membrane-proximal region of the integrin β2 cytoplasmic tail. (A) The sequence of the β2 cytoplasmic peptides. (B) Radixin N-ERMAD binds to the membrane-proximal region of the β2 cytoplasmic tail. Interaction between the different β2 cytoplasmic peptides and radixin N-ERMAD were determined by ELISA as above. (C) Inhibition of N-ERMAD binding to the β2 cytoplasmic peptide by CTΔ31. Radixin N-ERMAD binding to the β2 cytoplasmic tail was performed as above, except in the presence different soluble peptides. Data are means±S.D. of duplicate samples and are representative of two independent experiments. sCTΔ31, scrambled CTΔ31.

Cytohesin-1 and radixin N-ERMAD recognize overlapping regions of the β2 cytoplasmic tail. (A) Cytohesin-1 binding to the β2 cytoplasmic tail. His-cytohesin-1 binding to the β2 cytoplasmic tail in the presence of different β2 peptides was performed as above. (B) Competition between Cytohesin-1 and radixin. Binding of GST-radixin N-ERMAD to the β2 cytoplasmic tail was conducted as in Fig. 1 except in the presence of His-tagged cytohesin-1 (□) or a control protein BSA (∘). Data are means±S.D. of duplicate samples and are representative of two independent experiments.

Expression of the N-terminal radixin promotes integrin adhesive activity. (A) Pull-down assays. Cell lysates from αMβ2-expressing CHO cells were passed through either GST-N-ERMAD (lanes 1 and 3) or GST (lanes 2 and 4)-column. After washing, the bound proteins were analyzed by SDS–PAGE and immunoblotted with anti-β2 cytoplasmic tail (lanes 1 and 2) or anti-GST (lanes 3 and 4). (B) The effect of radixin N-ERMAD on cell adhesion. Different radixin fragments were expressed in αMβ2/CHO cells and their adhesion to the Fg γ-module (10μg/ml) was determined in the presence or absence of an αMβ2-specific inhibitor NIF (10nM). After washing, representative adherent cells were photographed with 20× differential interference contrast (DIC) lens using the Zeiss Axiovert 200M system. Scale bars: 20μm. (C) The numbers of adherent cells in (B) were quantified by staining with Crystal violet and measuring absorption at 570nm. The specificity of the adhesion assay was confirmed by lack of cell adhesion of mock transfected cells. (D) Conformational changes within the αMβ2 receptor. αMβ2/CHO cells expressing either N-ERMAD or GFP were incubated with 1μg of mAb 24 at 37°C or 2LPM19c in the presence of 1mM Ca2+/1mM Mg2+ for 30min. Bound mAb 24 or 2LPM19c was determined by flow cytometry using R-Phycoerythrin conjugated anti-mouse IgG. An isotype matched non-immune IgG was used as a control (not shown). Mean fluorescence intensity of mAb 24, calculated using a FACScan program (BD Biosciences, Mountain View, CA) and normalized by surface expression of the receptor (based on 2LPM19c staining), was used as an activation index. N-ERMAD-expressing αMβ2/CHO cells exhibited significantly higher mAb 24 binding compared to those expressing GFP (∗, P=0.002). Data are means±S.D. of duplicate samples and are representative of three independent experiments.

The integrin β2 cytoplasmic domain binding site within the radixin FERM domain. (A) Sequence alignment between the cytoplasmic domains of ICAM-2 and integrin β2. Functional residues that are conserved between these two proteins are shown in boxes. (B) The β2 binding site within the radixin FERM domain. A schematic drawing of the β2 cytoplasmic tail/radixin FERM complex was prepared from the crystal structure of the radixin/ICAM-2 complex [22]. The β2 peptide is represented in red. The radixin FERM domain is composed of three subdomains: Fl (in cyan), F2 (in orange) and F3 (in green). The conserved residues are shown in balls and sticks.

head.ce:title: Cytoskeletal protein radixin activates integrin αMβ2 by binding to its cytoplasmic tail

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Center for Vascular and Inflammatory Diseases, Department of Physiology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 800 W Baltimore Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Talin binding of integrins, via its band 4.1, ezrin, radixin, and moesin (FERM)-homologous domain, directly activates the integrin receptor. However, it is not known whether other FERM-containing proteins also possess such an integrin activating capability. We report here that radixin, one of the original FERM-domain proteins, binds to the membrane-proximal region of the integrin β2 but not αM cytoplasmic tail. Importantly, we show that radixin binding significantly enhances the adhesive activity of integrin αMβ2. Given the distinct biological activities of radixin and talin, radixin may represent a novel talin-independent pathway for integrin activation under specific settings.

ce:keyword.ce:text: the band 4.1, ezrin, radixin, and moesin-homologous domain
sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis
The band 4.1, ezrin, radixin, and moesin-homologous domain

ce:section.ce:para: Recent studies suggest that talin binding to the cytoplasmic domain of integrin receptors represents the final step in integrin activation (“inside-out” signaling) [1]. Talin comprises of an N-terminal 50-kDa head region that is homologous to the FERM domain, and a C-terminal 205-kDa rod region, which regulates the function of the N-terminal head via intra- and inter-molecular interactions. Talin can be activated by calpain-mediated proteolysis [2] or by phosphoinositide binding [3], and once activated, it binds, through the phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domain located within its FERM-homologous region, to a highly conserved NPxY motif within the integrin β cytoplasmic tail [4,5]. Integrin engagement by talin subsequently disrupts a salt bridge between its α and β cytoplasmic domains [6], leading to its activation [5]. Interestingly, although a number of proteins, including syk, Numb, and Dok, contain a PTB domain that interacts with the integrin β cytoplasmic tail with high affinity, however, none of them was capable of activating integrin receptor [5]. Thus, the talin FERM domain seems very unique in its integrin activating capability.

In this study, we searched for additional proteins that are capable of activating integrins. We report here the identification of another FERM protein radixin that possesses similar integrin activating activities. Using αMβ2 (Mac-1, CD11b/CD18) as a representative of integrin receptors, we demonstrate that radixin binds to the membrane-proximal region of the integrin β cytoplasmic tail via its N-terminal ezrin–radixin–moesin family (ERM) associated domain (N-ERMAD). We show that radixin binding to integrin αMβ2 enhances its adhesive activity. Together, our study identifies radixin as an important player in integrin “inside-out” signaling in addition to talin. As radixin recognizes the integrin cytoplasmic tail differently than talin, radixin may represent a novel talin-independent pathway for integrin activation under specific settings.

MGIN [7] was provided by Dr. R.G. Hawley (American Red Cross, Rockville, MD). IB4, OKM1, and TS1/18 were from ATCC (Rockville, MD); mAb 44 and 2LPM19c were from Sigma (St. Louis, MO). mAb 24 [8] was provided by Dr. Nancy Hogg (Imperial Cancer Research Fund, London, UK). Recombinant γ-module of fibrinogen (Fg) was provided by Dr. L. Medved (University of Maryland, MD). Neutrophil inhibitor factor (NIF) [9] was provided by Dr. E. Plow (Cleveland Clinic Foundation, OH). All other reagents were of the highest grade available from Sigma Chemical Co. (St Louis, MO) unless otherwise noted.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Expression of recombinant radixin in E. coli
ce:section.ce:para: To express the radixin N-ERMAD (1–298) and C-ERMAD (281–584) in E. coli, their corresponding cDNAs were amplified using the following pairs of primers: 5′-AAAGGATCC-ATGCCGAAGCCAATCAATGTAAGAGT-3′ and 5′-TCAGTCGACTT-AATCAGGCTTTCTCCTTCGCATGTACAG-3′, and 5′-AAAGGATCCTTGGCCTTATGTATGG-GAAACATGAA-3′ and 5′-GAAGTCGACTCACATGGCTTCAAACTCATCGATGCG-3′, and then cloned into pGEX-4T-1 (for glutathione-s-transferase (GST) fusion; Amersham, Piscataway, NJ) and pET-32a (for histidine-tag fusion; Novagen, Madison, WI). Cytohesin-1 was expressed as a histidine-tagged protein using pQE-31 (QIAgen). Generation of recombinant proteins in E. coli BL21(DE3) and their purification using the glutathione–Sepharose or Ni–NTA column have been described previously [9]. The concentrations of the purified proteins were determined spectrophotometrically using the equation C (mg/ml)=(A280–A320)/1.45 and the concentrations were further verified by Coomassie blue-stained SDS–PAGE using BSA as a standard.

Ninety six-well polystyrene microtiter plates (Costar, Corning, NY) were coated with different synthetic peptides (1mg/ml) overnight at 4°C and post-coated with 10% milk for 1h at room temperature. GST-tagged radixin fragments or His-tagged cytohesin-1 (both at 150nM) in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) plus 0.1%BSA were added and incubated for 40min at room temperature. After washing with PBS, bound GST-radixin was detected using a horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-anti-GST conjugate, and an HRP substrate 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine, measuring absorption at 550nm (A550).

Cells expressing αMβ2, which were established previously [10], were lysed in 20mM Tris–HCl, 150mM NaCl, pH 7.4, 0.25% deoxycholate, 1% p-nitrophenyl-p-guanidinobezoate, 2mM EGTA, 1mM PMSF, 10mM benzamidine, 25μg/ml SBTI, and 20μg/ml leupeptin. After centrifugation, cell lysates were incubated with GST-radixin N-ERMAD that was immobilized onto a glutathione agarose column. After washing, bound proteins were eluted and then analyzed by 10% SDS–PAGE. The presence of αMβ2 was detected by immunobloting using an anti-β2 cytoplasmic domain antibody [11] and visualized using an HRP conjugate of goat anti-rabbit IgG.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Establishment of Chinese hamster cells (CHO) expressing both integrin αMβ2 and radixin
ce:section.ce:para: To express αMβ2 and radixin simultaneously, cDNAs encoding N-ERMAD and C-ERMAD were inserted individually into the expression vector MGIN [7], in which radixin expression is tightly linked to green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression via an internal ribosome entry site (IRES). These expression plasmids were transfected, together with a expression vector containing the hygromycin cDNA, into the αMβ2-expressing CHO cells that we previously established [10]. After selection with 200μg/ml hygromycin, stable clones that express equivalent amount of αMβ2 and radixin were established by dual-color cell sorting using a mAb anti-αM (OKM1) and GFP as cell sorting markers.
Cell adhesion was conducted using Fg or its αMβ2-recognition domain, the γ-module [10,12], based on our published procedures [13].

ce:section.ce:section-title: The N-terminal FERM domain of radixin interacts with the β2 cytoplasmic tail
ce:section.ce:para: To see if talin is the only FERM domain-containing protein that is capable of activating integrins, we tested the ability of radixin to interact with the β2 integrin cytoplasmic tail. Given that radixin exists in an inactive state due to an intramolecular interaction between its N- and C-terminal ERMADs [14], we expressed N-ERMAD (residues 1–298) and C-ERMAD (residues 281–584) separately as either GST- or His-tagged proteins. All of the recombinant proteins exhibited expected molecular sizes and were more than 90% pure (data not shown).

Interactions between radixin fragments and integrin cytoplasmic tails were assessed by ELISA. Thus, 96-well microtiter plates were coated with αM (CYKLGFFKRQYKDMMSEGGPPGAEPQ) or β2 (CWKALIHLSDLREYRRFEKEKLKSQWNNDNPLFKSATTTVMNPKFAES) cytoplasmic peptides. Different concentrations of radixin fragments were added and bound proteins were quantified. As shown in Fig. 1A, N-ERMAD bound the β2 cytoplasmic peptide dose-dependently with a Kd of 110±27nM, whereas no significant binding activity was observed for C-ERMAD. Moreover, neither radixin fragments interacted with the αM cytoplasmic peptide. Furthermore, no binding to an irrelevant peptide SW63 (CSTHFPGGGSISHSGHF) or a scrambled peptide sCTΔ31 (CLYRLEWFHAILRSRKD) was observed for N-ERMAD (data not shown), verifying the specificity of the binding assay. These data demonstrated that radixin recognizes the β2 integrin cytoplasmic tail via its N-terminal FERM domain.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Inhibition of N-ERMAD binding to integrin cytoplasmic domain by C-ERMAD
ce:section.ce:para: To see if N-ERMAD binding to the integrin β2 cytoplasmic domain is controlled by C-ERMAD, we conducted the above binding assays in the presence of His-tagged C-ERMAD. Addition of C-ERMAD at ratios of 2:1 and 4:1 (C-ERMAD:N-ERMAD) both led to significant inhibition on N-ERMAD binding to the β2 cytoplasmic peptide (Fig. 1B). As expected, N-ERMAD did not interact with the αM cytoplasmic tail with or without C-ERMAD.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Radixin binds to the membrane-proximal region of the integrin β2 cytoplasmic tail
ce:section.ce:para: To localize the functional sequence within the integrin β2 cytoplasmic tail for radixin recognition, we tested N-ERMAD binding to truncated β2 cytoplasmic peptides (Fig. 2A). We found that removal of NPxY/F, the sequence recognized by talin, did not significantly affect N-ERMAD binding as both truncated β2 peptides CTΔ19 and CTΔ31 bound N-ERMAD well (Fig. 2B). In fact, they exhibited higher binding activity toward N-ERMAD than the full length peptide. Verifying specificity, N-ERMAD did not bind to either the scrambled peptide sCTΔ31 or BSA-coated wells.

To further confirm the involvement of the membrane-proximal region of the β2 cytoplasmic tail in radixin recognition, the ability of soluble CTΔ31 to inhibit N-ERMAD binding of the full length β2 cytoplasmic peptide was tested. Thus, N-ERMAD was added to β2 peptide-coated 96-well plates in the presence of different concentrations of CTΔ31. After washing, bound N-ERMAD was determined as above. Fig. 2C shows that CTΔ31, which contains only the membrane-proximal 16 residues, competed effectively with the full length β2 peptide for radixin binding with a C50 of 25μM, whereas its scrambled control peptide sCTΔ31 or DMSO had no effect. Together, these data demonstrated that the NPxY/F sequence within the β2 cytoplasmic domain, which is critical to talin recognition, is not required for radixin binding.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Radixin and cytohesin-1 recognize overlapping binding sites within the β2 cytoplasmic tail
ce:section.ce:para: Cytohesin-1 activates αLβ2 by binding to residues 723–731 of β2 [15]. To see if cytohesin-1 and radixin share a common recognition site within β2, we conducted additional binding experiments. Fig. 3A shows that cytohesin-1 binding to the full length β2 peptide was effectively inhibited by soluble CTΔ31 in a dose- dependent manner, whereas additions of similar concentrations of DMSO or an irrelevant peptide SW63 had no effect and addition of (sCTΔ31) yielded much weaker inhibition.

To further confirm that radixin and cytohesin-1 recognize an overlapping site within the β2 cytoplasmic tail, we tested if radixin and cytohesin-1 could compete directly with each other for binding to the β2 cytoplasmic peptide. We found that indeed cytohesin-1 competed with radixin N-ERMAD effectively with a C50 of 0.2μM, whereas addition of BSA did not have significant effect (Fig. 3B).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Radixin binds integrin αMβ2 in total cell lysates
ce:section.ce:para: To test if radixin interacts with integrin receptors in whole cell lysates, we carried out pull-down experiments between radixin N-ERMAD and αMβ2, a major β2 integrin expressed on leukocytes. Fig. 4A shows that radixin N-ERMAD but not GST, both of which were immobilized onto glutathione–Sepharose resin, could effectively pull down αMβ2, as demonstrated by the presence of a 95kDa protein by immunoblot using anti-β2 polyclonal antibody. Additional immunoblot analyses of the pull-down products with anti-GST antibody verified that equally amount of GST and GST-N-ERMAD were present on the resin.

To test if radixin binding to the β2 cytoplasmic domain could result in integrin activation, we transfected N-ERMAD or C-ERMAD of radixin into αMβ2-expressing CHO cells, using the retroviral vector MGIN [7]. Stable cell lines that express equivalent levels of αMβ2 on the cell surface and similar levels of radixin were established by cell sorting using both the αM-specific mAb OKM1 and GFP as markers. Surface expression of αMβ2 by the different clones and also pools of the αMβ2/radixin/CHO cells used in this study differed by less than twofold (mean fluorescence intensity: 1594 for GFP, 1433 for C-ERMAD pool, 1035 for N-ERMAD clone 6, and 2555 for N-ERMAD pool). Cell adhesion experiments demonstrated that expression of radixin N-ERMAD in αMβ2/CHO cells significantly increased the adhesive activity of αMβ2 toward the Fg γ-module, a representative αMβ2 ligand (Fig. 4B). Expression of radixin N-ERMAD increased the number of adherent αMβ2/CHO cells more than threefold when compared to that of GFP (radixin vs. GFP, P<0.005), whereas expression of radixin C-ERMAD had no effect (Fig. 4C). Verifying specificity of the adhesion assays, addition of EDTA or NIF, a high affinity αMβ2-specific inhibitor [9], completely blocked the αMβ2-mediated cell adhesion. Moreover, no significant adhesion to the Fg γ-module was observed for mock-transfected CHO cells (Fig. 4C). Finally, to investigate whether radixin N-ERMAD promoted the adhesive activity of αMβ2 by changing its conformation, we conducted FACS analyses using an activation-specific mAb (mAb 24), which has been used previously by us [16,17] and others [8,18] to probe the activation status of αMβ2. Fig. 4D shows that expression of radixin N-ERMAD significantly increased mAb 24 binding to αMβ2 (P=0.002), suggesting that in the presence of radixin N-ERMAD αMβ2 exists in an active conformation. Thus, radixin N-ERMAD most likely enhanced αMβ2-mediated cell adhesion by activating the receptor.

Talin is the only known FERM-containing protein capable of integrin activation [1]. In this study, we identified another FERM domain-containing protein radixin that exhibits similar integrin activation capability. Compared to talin, radixin exhibits two distinct features: first, unlike talin, radixin recognizes the membrane-proximal region but not the NPxY/F sequence within the integrin β cytoplasmic tail; and second, talin but not radixin, is sensitive to calpain proteolysis and activation [19]. Thus, radixin may function as a talin-independent integrin activation pathway under specific settings.

Radixin interacts with the cytoplasmic domains of a number of cell surface proteins, including ICAM-1, ICAM-2, ICAM-3, CD44, and CD43 [20,21]. Though no consensus sequences among these different cytoplasmic domains have been identified for radixin binding, most of the known radixin recognition sequences reside within the membrane-proximal regions and contain clusters of hydrophobic and positively charged residues [21]. Indeed, results from this study demonstrate that radixin binds to the membrane-proximal region of integrin β2, which shares a significant homology with the radixin-recognition sequence within ICAM-2, especially surrounding those resides (shown in boxes, Fig. 5A) that are in direct contacts with the PTB/F3 domain of radixin (Fig. 5B) [22]. Accordingly, we hypothesize that the LxxLxxYRRF sequence within the β2 cytoplasmic domain, a sequence that is homologous to the radixin-binding site (YxxLxxWRRL) within ICAM-2, represents the major recognition site for radixin (Fig. 5B, conserved residues are shown in balls and sticks). Experiments to test this hypothesis are under way.

In summary, using a number of different approaches, we have established radixin as an important player in integrin activation. Our data demonstrate that radixin is capable of binding and activating the β2 integrin receptor, thus identifying radixin as the second FERM-containing protein, in addition to talin, that supports integrin “inside-out” signaling. As radixin and talin recognize different regions of the integrin cytoplasmic tail, and are activated by independent intracellular signaling pathways, for example, radixin is activated by Rho-dependent kinase (ROCK) [23] and phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate 5-kinase [24], whereas talin is primarily activated by calpain-mediated cleavage [2], radixin may represent a novel talin-independent pathway for integrin activation under specific settings.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We thank Drs. Hawley, Medved, Hogg and Plow for providing valuable reagents. This work was supported in part by grants (R01 HL61589 and P01 HL54710) from the National Institutes of Health.
